entities.name: uncle vernon
entities.description: Uncle Vernon is described as maintaining an opinion about his son. He says he doesn't want a 'swotty little nancy boy' for a son. (Excerpt: '“he didn’t want some swotty little nancy boy for a son anyway.”')

entities.name: aunt petunia
entities.description: Aunt Petunia is described as tearfully defending her nephew. She says he's 'boisterous' but wouldn't hurt a fly. (Excerpt: ‘“He’s a boisterous little boy, but he wouldn’t hurt a fly!”')

entities.name: dudley
entities.description: Dudley is described as being big-boned and needing plenty of food. However, the school nurse's comments suggest that this may not be the case. (Excerpt: 'Aunt Petunia had said tearfully... but the fact remained that the school outfitters didn’t stock knickerbockers big enough for him anymore.')

entities.name: school nurse
entities.description: The school nurse is described as making comments about Dudley's weight. Her comments are not explained away by Uncle Vernon and Aunt Petunia. (Excerpt: 'No matter how much Aunt Petunia wailed that Dudl ey was big-boned... the fact remained that the school outfitters didn’t stock knickerbockers bi g enough for him anymore.')

relationships.description: Uncle Vernon disapproves of Dudley. He says he doesn't want a 'swotty little nancy boy' for a son. (Excerpt: ‘“he didn’t want some swotty little nancy boy for a son anyway.”')
Aunt Petunia defends Dudley. She says he's 'boisterous' but wouldn't hurt a fly. (Excerpt: ‘“He’s a boisterous little boy, but he wouldn’t hurt a fly!”')

The school nurse observes Dudley's weight and makes comments about it. Her comments are not explained away by Uncle Vernon and Aunt Petunia. (Excerpt: 'No matter how much Aunt Petunia wailed that Dudl ey was big-boned... the fact remained that the school outfitters didn’t stock knickerbockers bi g enough for him anymore.')
